intro: Sambucus neomexicana, commonly known as the New Mexico elderberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Adoxaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces dark purple berries that are edible when ripe, though they are often used in traditional medicine. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Sambucus neomexicana plays an important role in supporting local wildlife and is valued for its ornamental and ecological significance.
